guide.title: Gentoo Weekly Newsletter
guide.subtitle: 5 February 2007
guide.abstract: This is the Gentoo Weekly Newsletter for the week of 5 February 2007.

body.p: I don't think zzam needs introducing. Though for those who don't know who he i and/or what he does, here is a small summary:

Matthias Schwarzott, also known as zzam, is a 25 year old developer from
Erlangen,Germany. He lives there with his lovely girlfriend Charlotte on the 8th floor of a tall Apartment. The view he looks outside from the balconies, is -by the way- splendid (view1 view2). So far Matthias doesn't own pets, though he's pity he lives in an apartment with limited space for a cat.

Matthias studies technomathematics, which is basicly an expensive word for mathematics and technology, at the Friedrich Alexander University of Erlangen-Nuremberg. Most of the technology is programming in java, working with algorithms and programming computer graphics in c++. He also get technical background about electronical engeneering. To give an example of a practical technical aspect of his studies: Matthias recently finished a thesis on model integrated circuits in VHDL (Very High Speed Integrated Circuit Hardware Description Language), a language to model ICs. He implemented PONG in our practica on an fpga, some kind of configurable hardware.

While he studied, he already achieved some pratical experrience at Siemens, where He was a c/c++ programmer. Though Matthias recently started working part-time as an systems administrator at a small company which operates web-games. When zzam is done with these studies, which are still one semester, Matthias hopes to be able to start working somewhere as a programmer.

Matthias started using linux in the summer of '97 when he was tired of Windows 3.11 . At that time, he bought suse 5.0 at a local book store after reading about it in a magazine. He also tried Debian before he finally decided to start to work with Gentoo Linux. He started using our operating system around the 1.4 version, which he has used ever since.

He only started to get interests of joining the developers team, after buying his dvb-card to set up a vdr-box. At first he used to compile the programs by hand, though a bit later on he started using a few ebuilds from http://www.gentoo.de. After that he started contributing, under Stefan Schweizer's keen eye. After his recruitment-proces, Matthias became vdr-lead. Since then vdr has grown a lot! Though he's still looking for active contributors, since he wants to implement some patches and someone to help him maintain the patchsets he collected yet.

After a while it's fun to see how dvb on windows isn't that great compared to the raw power of vdr. This, and off course seeying happy users, is exactly what gives zzam stamina to go on with his work.

Though he's pretty busy with his studies, his part-time job and gentoo, Matthias still (fortunately) got some free time left for his hobbies, which are practising classic dances (e.g. cha-cha/waltz/etc.), cooking and baking and doing fitness, which he only started doing recently. zzam started dancing at the end of his school time. At that time he took dancing classes, which he has recently restarted doing with his girlfriend at the jugendclub. There he tries to improve his skills.
As mentioned before, Matthias also likes baking and cooking. His favorite recipe's are streusel cake and self made pizza, which look very yummie.

At the end we asked Matthias how he things gentoo will look like in 10 years. After a minute, he answered the following: "I think in 10 years (if no hard break occured) gentoo will have a high number of devs. Though gentoo is in need of a better team management, to let teams work better together. Also I think that gentoo needs an improved version of bugday."
Hanno Boeck recently added Metisse to his svn overlay. Metisse is the answer from Mandriva to compiz, and the whole 3d-desktop thing.

Metisse has some some features that gives the possibility to transform the natural shape of windows. A few examples of this are: rotating, scaling, zooming your windows. You can even make a parallellogram from your window! Mettisse runs on its own native X-Server, which is luminocity/xgl-alike and a modified variant of fvwm.

Unfortunately Metisse is still missing an amd64 version, but that is taken care of upstream. Also we're patiently waitint for a new version where the coders should fix some known bugs.
